prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

para.paratext: Panel decisions are normally made by written decision. Only rarely has the Panel decided transfer questions from the bench.[1] The Clerk of the Panel serves a copy of every decision to every person or party appearing on the ECF service list and on any pro se parties[2] for the action.

Many of the Panel's decisions were historically written by that prolific Scandinavian jurist, Per Curiam. The Panel has more recently generally issued its decisions signed by an individual member of the Panel, most often the Panel Chair.[3] In addition, members of the Panel have filed concurring or dissenting opinions in a few cases.[4] Judges have also dissented from decisions of the Panel without any opinion.[5]

The Panel does not have any public rules relating to publication or non-publication of its decisions. Historically, its earlier decisions were reported, and then for a period of years the majority of its decisions were not published. Many of its early decisions are published, the majority of them in Federal Supplement. An occasional Panel decision is published in Federal Rules Decisions[6] and many appear in specialized looseleaf or topical reporters.[7] More recently, many decisions are reported, and they are more consistently published in Federal Supplement 2d. The looseleaf reporters contain decisions that are generally also reported in the West reporters and on WestLaw. Federal Supplement remains the primary source for Panel decisions, and the decisions appear in the F. Supp. advance sheets promptly after release. Panel decisions are also available on Lexis and Westlaw shortly after release. Recent decisions, including many not published elsewhere, are available on the Panel's website, http://www.jpml.courts.gov. The website does not contain an archive of older decisions however.

In most cases the Panel decides the matter before it within a short period after arguments are held or after the briefing is completed if the parties waive oral argument. Occasionally, the Panel will defer issuing a decision for some particular reason related to the proceedings in the case.[8] The Panel normally issues its decision as a single order or opinion. The Panel has, however, entered summary orders shortly after a hearing with a notation in the decision that a memorandum of decision would be issued later.[9] Similarly, the Panel has decided a case by an early order, issued a memorandum of decision at a later time, and entered concurring and dissenting opinions at a still later date.[10]

The Panel does not have a rule limiting the use of unpublished decisions, and occasionally cites its own unpublished orders.[11] Given the pragmatic focus of the Panel's decisions, its prior decisions are not likely to have true precedential value. Nonetheless, the unpublished decisions may be useful to understand the Panel's judgements and decision-making process. The Panel undoubtedly also values consistency in its decisions, and an earlier decision, even unpublished, may be useful to encourage it to reach a similar result.
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
